body:
Thanks for bisecting.

That commit is a bugfix I'd say. I've noticed it while considering deprecating the nose compat however I decided against it for now as it would be useless churn for users.

homeassistent should either avoid these names, or probably better, disable the nose plugin (`-p no:nose`). That will work on all pytest versions, and avoid other nose surprises.
Fair, but I wonder if we could/should show a better message for that case?

> Fair, but I wonder if we could/should show a better message for that case?

Better error would be good (also relevant for pytest own names e.g. `setup_module` and such). IIUC `setup` in this case is a module which causes the error. I can look into improving the error message - can't guarantee when though :) Shall we open a separate issue or use this one to track this?

issue.title: Disable nose plugin in pytest configuration

repository.name: core
repository.description: :house_with_garden: Open source home automation that puts local control and privacy first.

issue.title: Type Error using patch decorator for 7.0.0rc1

labels.name: type: regression
labels.description: indicates a problem that was introduced in a release which was working previously

labels.name: plugin: nose
labels.description: related to the nose integration builtin plugin

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
```
    @patch("packge.class.method")
    def setup(self, mock_method):
```
The mentioned method is with decorated @staticmethod

Error 

```
    @wraps(func)
    def patched(*args, **keywargs):
        with self.decoration_helper(patched,
                                    args,
                                    keywargs) as (newargs, newkeywargs):
>           return func(*newargs, **newkeywargs)
E           TypeError: setup() takes 2 positional arguments but 3 were given

.eggs/mock-4.0.3-py3.6.egg/mock/mock.py:1346: TypeError

```

When I use pytest 6.2.5 I do not see this error. This error happens when using pytest 7.+

**Package   Version**     
coverage 5.6b1
pytest 7.0.0rc1     
pytest-cov 2.11.1
PyHamcrest 2.0.2
mock 4.0.3  
tomli 1.2.3

OS: Linux 14.04.6 LTS, Trusty Tahr
Python: Python 3.6.8

Note: Truncated details due to limitations on what I can share about the code and packages.
I can answer further questions if this information is unsufficient.

Quick check-list while reporting bugs:


- [x] a detailed description of the bug or problem you are having
- [x] output of `pip list` from the virtual environment you are using
- [x] pytest and operating system versions
- [x] minimal example if possible

body:
I just took a quick look at this with @cgtobi - Home Assistant actually [uses](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/27807869ee573dd8584818814a1b958be34186a7/tests/test_config.py#L57-L80) nose-style `setup`/`teardown` in a couple of places, so `-p no:nose` [leads to some issues](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/runs/4618000702?check_suite_focus=true#step:9:101).

I was wondering why this worked just fine for them despite the [`setup` import](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/8e759bb2674b006b75d80fcfdfe718ccdd6379d3/tests/test_setup.py#L12) in earlier pytest versions.

I think the reason is that before, we [used `call_optional` for module-level setup](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/pull/9273/files#diff-7604a56a6b5717387f31b1b63dd968b6da514dd5bc00fe5f7a349c144d33878aL24), which [silently ignores](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/pull/9273/files#diff-7604a56a6b5717387f31b1b63dd968b6da514dd5bc00fe5f7a349c144d33878aR37-L43) non-callable objects.

However, with #9273, we now [call it unconditionally](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/pull/9273/files#diff-daf6183b4d7b07f30f627784f859fdb941552b9895bc1b06a38ac33f37b0225fR865) despite it being a module object, which then results in the `AttributeError` for `__code__`.

Despite surely being a bit unorthodox in moduleassistant's code, I think this is a regression. Not sure what the best behavior here would be:

1) Either keep it as before and silently ignore it when it's not callable, or
2) Turn non-callable `setup`/`teardown` into an error (though we might want to deprecate it first, dunno?)

> Either keep it as before and silently ignore it when it's not callable, or

I vote for this, pytest should be "smart" here and figure out that an object is not callable. Not sure 2) would help users, other than forcing them to rename a module (`from foo import setup as something_else`).
Btw thanks for the report @cgtobi and for the investigation @The-Compiler!

issue.title: python: skip nose setup/teardown fixtures if non-callable

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
Since commit 89f0b5b5a2f485f77999d15cb9437ad9234003a1 cases as in the
added test started to fail, like they do for the standard pytest names
(`setup_module` etc). But the name `setup` in particular is way too
common for us to start taking it over more aggressively, so restore the
previous behavior which required the object to be callable.

Fix #9391.

<!--
Thanks for submitting a PR, your contribution is really appreciated!

Here is a quick checklist that should be present in PRs.

- [ ] Include documentation when adding new features.

If this change fixes an issue, please:

- [ ] Add text like ``closes #XYZW`` to the PR description and/or commits (where ``XYZW`` is the issue number). See the [github docs](https://help.github.com/en/github/managing-your-work-on-github/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue#linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue-using-a-keyword) for more information.

Unless your change is trivial or a small documentation fix (e.g., a typo or reword of a small section) please:

- [ ] Create a new changelog file in the `changelog` folder, with a name like `<ISSUE NUMBER>.<TYPE>.rst`. See [changelog/README.rst](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/main/changelog/README.rst) for details.

  Write sentences in the **past or present tense**, examples:

  * *Improved verbose diff output with sequences.*
  * *Terminal summary statistics now use multiple colors.*

  Also make sure to end the sentence with a `.`.

- [ ] Add yourself to `AUTHORS` in alphabetical order.
-->
